text: Undergrad about to finish another semester anyone know any good open source projects to contribute to I'm specifically looking at stuff related to Quantum computing or cryptography

text:
I'm not sure if there are any other projects surrounding QC in julia :confused:. However i can suggest some books, Neilsen and chuang is a great book: <http://mmrc.amss.cas.cn/tlb/201702/W020170224608149940643.pdf>
Can also check out these notes from university of washington: <https://homes.cs.washington.edu/~oskin/quantum-notes.pdf>

elements.text: I'm not sure if there are any other projects surrounding QC in julia
. However i can suggest some books, Neilsen and chuang is a great book:
Can also check out these notes from university of washington:

text:
There are a few more resources, I'll list them here, just in case,
• <https://quantum.country/|Quantum Computing for the very curious> - this is a good written introduction to the basics, and they even have email reminders for spaced repetition so that you remember stuff
• <https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=X2q1PuI2RFI&list=PL1826E60FD05B44E4|Quantum Computing for the determined> - a video series by the same person (Michael Nielsen) that created the first one 
• <https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PL701CD168D02FF56F|The Theoretical Minimum> - this is an intro to quantum mechanics. Despite the general advice that quantum mech is not that important a prerequisite for quantum comp, I personally found that watching these 10 videos was what cleared a lot of the questions that I had, so 11/10 would recommend
• <https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PL74Rel4IAsETUwZS_Se_P-fSEyEVQwni7|CS191x by Umesh Vazirani> - Arguably the most popular QM/QC course out there. Prof. Vazirani is a great teacher and you'll learn a lot. This is also considerably heavier than the first 2 links which are just very basic intro material.
Also, IBM has a very active community around Qiskit Quantum Computing, can check that out too.

attachments.title: Quantum Country
attachments.text: A free introduction to quantum computing and quantum mechanics
